page.title: 01Tilling Vale & West Rye
page.content: East/west snadstone ridges in for East Sussex are disected by the Tillingham and tributeries. An outlier forms the island of Rye. Sheep and cereals dominate. Apples, hops & soft fruit are important. Woodland is often oak/chestnet coppice. Pallets & fencing are produced. Sand and gravel extracted. But the dominent ecconomy is tourism. Inns, guest-houses, hotels and filling stations line the woods. Carparking is a problem and yacht berths scarce. Sheltered from the west by Fairlight Messif, the dry air, high light and architectural heritage attract artists and poets, potters and craftsmen. Rye traditionally dependent on steamship boatbuilding, fishing, wool-exports and transport, have wide contacts (also on the nearby continent). The over whelming source of history in the
